Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailIn the last few days, really big changes have been made to how we all live our lives. Boris Johnson last night ordered people only to leave their homes under a list of very limited purposes, banned public gatherings of more than two people and ordered the closure of non-essential shops.  The Government has changed how we are supposed to access services, who can and cannot go to school and hundreds of other things in a bid to contain the spread of Covid-. Predictably this has led to lots and lots of questions - because real le is often complicated in a way which is dficult for even the best-intentioned civil servant to imagine. So we asked you what questions you wanted to be answered and set about trying to get to the bottom of your query.We didnapost get answers to them all - and no doubt people will have a lot more in the next few days. So these answers are up to date as of pm on Tuesday, March . But things will change in the coming days as the Government continues to review its response to the coronavirus crisis. Can I move house  There is no government ban on moving house, and vehicle hire services remain open. But a Cabinet minister advised to postpone ityou can. Michael Gove accepted there will be “specic circumstances” where the process is already under way, meaning people continue to buy or sell homes amid the pandemic. But he suggested a “pause”possible adding: “If at all possible, people should stay in their current home.”  Can I still play golf  No. “I don’t think people should be playing golf,” minister Michael Gove said. Clubhouses are likely to be shut anyway. He said people should define exercise specically as “one walk, one run or one cycle per day”.Can I still go to my allotment  Yes. Michael Gove said: “I think it’s perfectly sensible for people to go to an allotment. It’s in the very nature of allotments that there’s a safe distance between people who are working on an inidual allotment.” Is there a limit on how long my daily walk can be  No, but people are asked to use common sense. Cabinet minister Michael Gove said: “People can go for the standardof run or walk that they ordinarily would have done. The important thing is once per day.”  Are over s allowed out to shop  Yes, but try to avoid it. Over-s may go out to buy essentialsabsolutely necessary, but they are in an “at-risk” group. This means they should take even greater care to stay indoors than most people and,they can, ask a friendly neighbour or family member to drop food at the door instead. However, the government is not explicitly telling all over-s to stay indoors at all times no matter what. That instruction has gone only to those who are either in a household with symptoms, or one of the .million most at risk people . Can I still deliver food to relatives or volunteer for strangers  Yes. Cabinet minister Michael Gove said dropping food at vulnerable people’s doors “is an appropriate activity”. He added: “Making sure the vulnerable receive the support they need is absolutely critical.”  What happensI get ‘caught’ in a group of more than two  People gathering in groups of more than two can be handed a £ fixed penalty notice by police - which can rise and lead to a criminal convictionunpaid. The exception isyou’re in the same household. It’s still unclear how this will be policed exactly.  Am I allowed to go to banks and post offices  Boris Johnson said pretty clearly that people are to go shopping for essential foods, medical appointments or shopping or to help or care for the vulnerable. But what about banks  They remain open, but are you allowed to go Yes. People may go “infrequently” to these placesit is “essential”, for instance posting legal papers or essential financial work. A No spokesman told us: “The businesses that were left open were on the basis that they are providing essential services to the public. The reasons for that speak for themselves. We’ve set out that people should leave the housethey need to collect items infrequently.”  Can I get petrol and an MOT on my car  Yes - for petrol, see above but bear in mind you shouldnapost be making any non-essential travel at all including in the UK. For MOTs, the Driver and Vehicle Standards Agencyhas said it is keeping the situation under review. But for the moment, cars, motorbikes, light vans will still need a valid MOT. Garages were specically excluded from those businesses that had to close, but you should check with your local mechanic about what their opening hours are. The DVSA has suspended testing of all heavy goods vehicles , trailers and public service vehiclesfor up to three months and said it is keeping testing of other vehicles under review. Can I drive to collect someone from the airport  There is no restriction on collecting people from the airport specically, but everyone has been asked to avoid all non-essential travel.  Picking up someone from the airport can fall into the category of essential travel - but it might be advisable to bring proof of their flight in case you are asked about your journey. I don’t live with my boyfriend or girlfriend - can I visit them   It seems not. Brits should not visit their boyfriendaposs or girlfriendaposs housethey donapost live together, Downing Street said. The governmentaposs rules explicitly say: You should be ensuring you are  metres apart from anyone outside of your household. Downing Street said: The guidance was clear yesterday. Essentially, what it said was that you should stay at home, and then it just set out four very specic circumstances where you may be permitted to go outdoors. And I think those rules should be applied to all scenarios. The exceptions are key workers taking kids to school, or split parents with shared custody iding time with kids. The Deputy Chief Medical Officer today confirmed boyfriends and girlfriends who live apart should stay apart. But she did offer a silver lining - saying lovers can move in with each other full-time and stay therethey want to take the plunge.  Why are warehouse and construction workers still having to go into work  Because the government has decided to let some people who aren’t “key workers” keep going into work. The government says people should not go into work in person unless it is absolutely necessary. But unless a firm has been forcibly shut down, the definition of “necessary” is being left up to employers to work out. In these firms, bosses are free to continue asking you to come to work. However, new rules were due to be issued on Tuesday to cover firms whose workers are still going in despite the lockdown. Health Secretary Matt Hancock said the rules would include a requirement on employers to keep workers  metres from each other. There will be unlimited fines for non compliance though they start at £, he said. Construction firms should also use “common sense” to ensure that distance is maintained, the government said. For instance large-scale construction sites have been told to go ahead - but domestic home extensions should be put on hold.  I work for an office relocation company. We are being told that clearing a building of desks, pens, chairs etc is an essential job. I disagree. How do I find out where we stand as I feel our health is being ignored  It seems this is a grey area. As above, firms can still ask workers to come in - even non key workers -it is “absolutely necessary” for them to be there in person. We asked Downing Streetworkers can refuse to go in - and didn’t get a clear answer. Instead, Boris Johnson’s spokesman said: “I think our guidance in relation to anybody who fears they may have symptoms or anybody in their house might have symptoms is very clear. We need people to stay at home because ultimately that will save lives.” Asked again, he said: “Well, the list of sectors in which we don’t consider to be essential was spelled out very clearly in the guidance we published last night. That was a direct instruction from the government and we would expect employers to adhere to it.” But No did not say what happens for firms that haven’t been told to shut down. I am an administrator for the NHS. I have equipment and access to systems and can easily work from home, but my manager insists I go to work. Where do I stand  Can I refuse  See above - this is not black-and-white. We are told it would be a discussion between the inidual and the employer . Government guidance says you should work from homeyou can, soyou believe that is the case, keep pressing it with your manager. Escalate it to the HR departmentneeds be. There may be a good reason for you being there in person ask what it is. Can my separated partner and I still share custody of our kids  Yes. Children under  are still allowed to travel between both of their parents’ homes, minister Michael Gove claried - moments after he said the exact opposite. However, he said moving between households in this case should be kept to a minimum.  Why hasnapost everyone received a government text  I have not received one, yet my we has The UKaposs mobile networks are sending out a Government message to their customers with details of the new shutdown measures. It reads: “GOV.UK CORONAVIRUS ALERT. New rules in force now: you must stay at home. More info and exemptions at gov.uk coronavirus Stay at home. Protect the NHS. Save lives.” But not all customers have already received the message yet. That is because mobile operators are sending them out in batches - because the network can become overwhelmed. O told the BBC it was sending the texts in batches adding it could take until :GMT to complete the task. My  year old mother needs a prescription for insulin in the next few days, and canapost get through to GP surgery. What do we do  Government guidance is clear GPs should be able to process prescriptions over the phone and they should be staying open for this purpose - but they will be busier than usual. Check their website or social media pages for any details about when they are open or any dficulties they are experiencing. Keep trying - and in the meantime try contacting your MP for help in getting through to the surgery. In the meantime in an emergency pharmacists are permitted to supply insulin - but only in the  only the smallest pack size available. So consider calling themthe situation doesn’t improve. Why do renters have to accrue debt, while homeowners get a three month mortgage holiday  The short answer is because that is the way the government has structured its support. It’s a political decision but ministers have said they keep the situation under review. Communities Secretary Robert Jenrick last week said: “The government is clear – no renter who has lost income due to coronavirus will be forced out of their home, nor will any landlord face unmanageable debts.” In short it means that private tenants will not be evicted from their homes for at least three months. Households and families could see their Council Tax bills slashed by £ as councils look to support those who fall into aposvulnerableapos groups. Anyone who receives Council Tax Support will be eligible for help.  Will employers pay the extra cost of utilities for those working from home  There are no Government instructions to force your employer to help you pay the cost of working from home. Meaning any arrangement would have to be struck between you and your employer. That doesn’t mean  there is no help available. If you need to pay for stuff like office chairs, desks the taxman can help ease the burden slightly. You will need to fill out a P form, which you can do so long as you have spent your own money on expenses that have not been reimbursed andyour allowable employment expenses are less than £, for the tax year. HMRC guidance stipulates you can claim relief for items aposwholly, exclusively and necessarilyapos in the performance of your employment role. Important note - you can only make a P claimyou and your employer have agreed that you have to work from home.

title: coronavirus church england closes churches
story: NewsCoronavirus: Church of England closes all churches for funerals, weddings and baptismsChurch weddings will be stopped, funerals will not take place inside church buildings, and only emergency baptisms will take place in hospitals or homesShareCommentsByJamie Hawkins:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsChurches across the country are closing due to the coronavirus pandemic " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailAll Church of England churches are to close with immediate effect, including for private prayer, in an effort to help limit the transmission of the coronavirus COVID-. The archbishops and bishops of the Church of England have written collectively to clergy, through their dioceses, urging them now to close all church buildings - other than where they are needed to keep a foodbank running, but even then under strict limits. There will be no church weddings until further notice funerals will not take place inside church buildings and the only baptisms will be emergency baptisms in a hospital or home. It follows the announcement by the Prime Minister last night of wide-ranging restrictions as part of a national and international effort to help limit the spread of the disease. “These are unprecedented times,” the bishops write. Do you have a coronavirus story to share  Email  webnews@mirror “We are all having to get used to being the Church dferently. “It is not easy. However, our belonging to Christ has never been measured by the number of people in church on a Sunday morningbut by the service we offer to others. “Therefore, and despite these very harrowing restrictions, please do all that you can to minister to your people safely, especially to the sick, the vulnerable and the poor.” The letter also seeks to provide clarity that churches will now be closed for all private prayer – including by priests.  Clergy live-streaming worship should do so from their own homes and are being urged to be as creative as possible with streaming services and other resources. “We must take a lead in showing our communities how we must behave in order to slow down the spread of the Coronavirus. “We must also do all that we can to provide resources and support for those who are isolated, fearful and vulnerable. “But we have to do this from our homes.” The Church of England will be offering a national weekly service which will be broadcast online each Sunday via social media and daily audio of prayer during the day and night prayer will also be available.  This is in addition to a wide range of resources local churches are sharing. An five million people heard or saw a service led by the Archbishop of Canterbury streamed online and broadcast through dozens of radio stations on Sunday – the largest single ‘congregation’ in the history of the Church of England. The bishops add: “It is also imperative that as the Church of Jesus Christ, called to offer hope and light in the darkness of this world’s ills, we maintain a praying presence for our community, though from today onwards this must happen from our hearts and from our homes.

title: coronavirus family reeling people ignore
story: NewsCoronavirus: Family reeling as people ignore rules while dad, , diesThe devastated widow of Phil Champion, who died at the Royal Cornwall Hospital, said it was "unbelievable" that people have not been following social distancing guidelinesShareCommentsByNick Irving:,  MAR NewsCoronavirus victim Phil Champion, , with his we Viv" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email The reeling widow of a man who died from coronavirus said her family cannot believe people are still ignoring advice on social distancing.Phil Champion, , died at the Royal Cornwall Hospital on Saturday after contracting the deadly virus. His we Viv said it was unbelievable some people are ignoring government advice on social distancing - and pleaded with them to do so however daft it may sound. Phil fell ill on March  - and his family have been told that his funeral could be held with just  mourners present. Viv, from Tywardreath, Cornwall, said:He felt very shivery and had a bit of a cough. The next morning he had a slighty upset tummy. For live updates on the coronavirus pandemic, click here He was admitted to hospital on March  and two days later was diagnosed with coronavirus. Phil was placed on a ventilator to help him breathe but his condition deteriorated over the next few days. His we said: Sadly that was the last time anyone was able to speak to him. Despite the massive efforts of the hospital they were not able to save him.  She said it was not known where or when he contracted the virus and says he was a fun loving man who was fit and active although not in perfect health. Viv said:He was a family man who we never thought would be a victim of this terrible illness. We would not want another family to go through what we have done - so follow the Governmentaposs advice. story: NewsCoronavirus: Fit and and healthy mum made will for daughter fearing she would dieA fit and healthy woman has told how she struggled to fight off Covid- and relied on wine gums and Manuka honey to keep her strength up after contracting the virusShareCommentsByRosaleen Fenton:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsAndrea has warned others to stay home after she contracted coronavirus " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA fit and healthy mum has told how she wrote a will for her young daughter before she was left fighting for her le after getting coronavirus. Mum Andrea Dolce Little, , posted on her Facebok page a warning for everyone who is not taking this seriously. She does does not smoke or drink much alcohol - but says she still found herself fighting for her le.  And she told how she relied on wine gums, haribos, fruit pastiles, two spoonfuls of Manuka honey and Berocca to keep her strength up. Ms Little, of Chilton, County Durham, warned against drinks with articial sweeteners such as Diet Coke and Pepsi as they will make you feel like you have been poisoned.In a post on Facebook, which has been shared over , times, she wrote: I’m glad to be passed the worst of it, but I wanted to share with you because a lot of yous are not taking this serious.It’s no joke, the cough you have is not a chesty cough it’s a dry cough, a cough where their is nothing to cough up. I’m a pretty healthy person apart from I have no thyroid, I do not smoke, I don’t not drink Much, I do not like drugs, I’m healthy and still this happened. I was worried enough for me to make a will for my daughter and tell her where everything was and how much it’s worth that’s how bad it gets. Some people will not get so bad it’s true but donapost risk it, isolate and keep away from ppl you loveyou have symptoms.Andrea said her first symptoms included suffering from a headache, runny nose and a sore throat. But by day three, the virus had shted to her chest. She wrote: I could not breath only the top section of my lungs would work like I was suffocating. The pain every time I breathed in was like my lungs were heavy and full of glass it hurt to breath. By day six, Andrea says she was completely wiped out and couldnapost move She wrote: My lungs were worse still no energy, could not walk or my legs would go shaking. I was so frightened my, full body was burning like it was on fire, the only time I could get a real breath was when I coughed and to cough it hurt. At this point, Andrea was rushed to hospital where she was put on a ventilator.  Describing the crisis, she wrote: I ended up on hospital on oxygen my back in so much pain with my lungs pains in my chest very dizzy and could not walk. Today I feel human but my lungs still hurt, but this virus it tricks you, you wake up some mornings and your ok you try to walk or do something and it’s back, it’s never ending. Now Andrea has urged others to follow the Government lockdown and stay at home.  She said: It’s true % of us will get this then we can build up a bit of an immune to it, but how many will die in the process I don’t know, look after the people you love and stay home. Hundreds of people have commented on Andreaaposs post since she uploaded it on March nd.  One well-wisher wrote: I was completely shocked and horried to read this. I can’t even imagine how traumatizing this must have been. Our thoughts and best wishes are with you. Another added: God bless you honey. Hope you feel better soon. A third person said: All the best glad youaposve pulled through and youaposve done this status is amazing. Hopefully will show ppl being ignorant to the situation open their eyes.It comes as the coronavirus death toll rose again to more than  yesterday.

My brother Billy is the number three person who has lost his le #x yesterday morning at am #x to this virus.#xCWhy am I sharing this  Because this is the hardest journey I#xve ever been on.#xDShe added: #xCThis virus is just ripping families apart. When my brother left his house on Friday night he thought he had a chest infection and he went into the hospital. I didn#xt know, or the family didn#xt know, we wouldn#xt be seeing Billy again.#xCWe couldn#xt be with Billy, we couldn#xt say goodbye, we couldn#xt be there, we can#xt even be together to bury Billy.#xDMs Fulton had a stark message for those failing to heed social distancing rules. #xCStop thinking about you, stop thinking about you,#xD she said.#xCBut think about others. This disease will kill many,you don#xt act properly #x stay at home. That#xs a simple message.#xD:Sadiq Khan hits back at Matt Hancock - TfL simply cannot safely run a full service because of staff sickness and self-isolationMore fallout from today#xs press briefing. Mayor of London Sadiq Khan#xs office has hit back at Matt Hancock#xs claim there was #xCno good reason#xD not to have more frequent services on the London saUnderground.A spokeswoman for the Mayor said: #xCThis is simply not true.#xCThe Mayor has told ministers countless times over recent days that TfL simply cannot safely run a full service because of the levels of staff sickness and self-isolation.#xCNearly a third of staff are already absent - there aren#xt enough drivers and control staff to do it.#xCThe Government must act urgently to get more people staying at home rather than going to work unnecessarily - that means taking the dficult decisions they are refusing to take to ban non-essential construction work and provide proper financial support to freelancers, the self-employed and those on zero-hours contracts to stay at home.#xD:Fresh guidance could be issued to schools tonightSpeaking after the meeting with the Education Secretary, NAHT general secretary Paul Whiteman said he expects to see fresh guidance issued to schools this evening.#xCThis should incorporate expert medical advice from Public Health England and practical steps that school leaders and their teams can take in order to stay safe,#xD he said.#xCThis guidance will be updated as more information becomes available.#xCSchool staff are playing a leading role in the fight against coronavirus and it is right that the Government should share with them the scientic evidence that underpins their approach and expert advice on safety precautions.#xD:Northern Ireland deaths rise to fiveThe total number of coronavirus-linked deaths in Northern Ireland has risen to five, Health Minister Robin Swann has announced.The two fatalities confirmed on Tuesday include -year-old Ruth Burke, whose family has already spoken publicly about her death in Antrim Area Hospital.Mr Swann said an earlier death in Northern Ireland had now been confirmed as being linked to Covid-.#xCMy deepest sympathies are extended to the families affected,#xD he said.#xCThese deaths must never become mere statistics. Behind each of them is a family plunged into grief.#xDRuth Burke, , with daughter Brenda:‘Dead and abandoned’ bodies found in care home by Spanish armyBodies are being found abandoned by squaddies in Spain tasked with disinfecting OAP care homes as part of the fight against coronavirus, it has emerged.Covid- victims have reportedly been found living with loved ones who are still alive.State prosecutors have already announced they are investigating a Madrid care home where it emerged last week  people had died, although regional health chiefs later lowered the number to .Read the full storyThe situation is becoming catastrophic in Spain :KEY EVENTBlame game erupts as people complain they are still being told to come into workA blame game has erupted over what work should and shouldn#xt continue during the coronavirus shutdown.Concerned workers have complained that they are being told to still come into work despite government advice being to work from home where posssible.Some trains on London#xs Tube network were crowded again on Tuesday morning despite Boris Johnson placing the UK on a police-enforced lockdown with drastic new measures in the fight against the coronavirus outbreak.The Prime Minister ordered people only to leave their homes under a list of #xCvery limited purposes#xD, banned public gatherings of more than two people and ordered the closure of non-essential shops.But police chiefs warned of phone lines being inundated with calls on Monday night with questions about what movements are still permitted, while MPs also called for answers.And the construction industry has been singled out - with people ided onmuch of the work which is happening at the moment is truly essential.In Downing St#xs daily briefing Matt Hancock said: #xCOf courseyou#xre in a workplace we#xve said will close we#xre going to enforce against those closures as well.#xDRead the full report Construction workers at work on City North development site in Finsbury Park, London, the day after Prime Minister Boris Johnson put the UK in lockdown to help curb the spread of the coronavirus :VIDEO: Matt Hancock announces temporary make-sht hospital and mass volunteers for the NHSLet#xsto the big news of the afternoon. Matt Hancock#xs announcements from the press briefing.:UK visa holders can extend their staythey cannothomeThe Home Office has said those with a visa who cannothome due to the COVID- pandemic will be able to extend their stay.The extension, announced todayby the Home Secretary Priti Patel, will apply to anyone whose leave expired after the  January and who cannot leave the country because of travel restrictions or self-isolation.This will last until  May but will be kept under regular review in case further extensions are needed.A dedicated COVID- immigration team has been set up within UKVI to make the process as straightforward as possible. Anyone in this situation just needs to contact this team, via this email address CIH@homeoffice.gov.uk, to let them know their visa has expired and they will be issued with an extension.To help those who want to apply for visas to stay in the UK long-term, the Home Office is also temporarily expanding the in-country switching provisions.:Robust and flexible plans” to keep staff and prisoners safeDowning Street said there were #xCrobust and flexible plans#xD to keep staff and prisoners safe. Prisons and the Ministry of Justice were examining how the social distancing rules could be complied with.The Prime Minister#xs official spokesman said: #xCWe do recognise the importance of continued contact with family.#xDMeanwhile, the University and College Unionhas called for face-to-face prison education to be suspended, raising concerns about workers#x safety.A small-scale poll conducted by the union found that % of prison education staff said hand washing facilities are inadequate, while % said classrooms are not cleaned between lessons and % said they are expected to share equipment, such as pens and keyboards, with other staff and prisoners.UCU general secretary Jo Grady said: #xCEducation has a vital role to play in prisons, but we must ensure the safety of staff and prisoners first and foremost, and do everything possible to limit the spread of the coronavirus. We want to work with the prison service to look at ways to get alternative learning materials to prisoners, but the face-to-face teaching must end for now.#xCIt is unacceptable that prison education staff are being asked to share equipment, work in dirty classrooms and undertake extra duties.#xD:All prison visits cancelled with jails on lockdownJails in England and Wales have been put on immediate lockdown with all visits cancelled, according to the union which represents prison officers.The POA said it #xCpraised the decision of the Secretary of State for Justice and the Director of Public Sector Prisons for their decision to place Prisons in England and Wales on immediate lockdown#xD.According to the union, restrictions inside jails will mean:- Inmates generally being locked up but allowed to access showers, phones and exercise - with social distancing restrictions in place- Prisoners who carry out kitchen, cleaning and laundry work can continue- No social visitsIn a statement, the POA also claimed prisoners due at court #xCwill be discharged to attend unless the courts service advise us otherwise#xD.The Ministry of Justicesaid: #xCWe have suspended all prison visits in England and Wales for today. This is while we ensure safe and secure ing of our prisons while enforcing social distancing.#xCIf you have a visit booked today, please do not attend.#xD:All prison visits cancelledAll prison visits have just been cancelled at prisons in London and all prisons across the UK.More follows.:People still have questions after that press briefing:. million antibody tests have been boughtHealth Secretary Matt Hancock said a new testing facility in Milton Keynes had opened today.He also said the UK had bought . million antibody tests to show whether people have had the virus.#xCI understand why NHS staff, in particular, and others across public service are so keen to get the testing ramped up, that we need to see and that we are undertaking,#xD he said.#xCOf course it really matters for getting people getting back to work, so we have now bought . million antibody tests.#xCThat will allow people to see whether they have had the virus and are immune to it and then can get back to work.#xD:We should have more tubes runningIn the press briefing, Matt Hancock said there should be more London Underground trains running.He said: #xCWhen it comes to the tube, the first and the best answer is that Transport for London should have the tube running in full so that people travelling on the tube are spaced out and can be further apart - obeying the two-metre rule wherever possible.#xCAnd there is no good reason in the information that I#xve seen that the current levels of tube provision should be as low as they are. We should have more tube trains running.#xD:Matt Hancock says construction workers can continue to work - so long as they remain two metres apart at all timesMr Hancock said construction workers could continue to go to work as long as they could remain two metres apart at all times.The Cabinet minister said: #xCThe judgment we have made is that in work, in many instances, the two-metre rule can be applied.#xCIn my work place, in the House of Commons, you can see it every day.#xCWhere possible, people should work from home and employers have a duty to ensure that people are more than two metres apart.#xCThe principles of what we are trying to achieve is to keep people apart to slow the spread.#xCThe more people follow the rules, the faster we will all get through this.#xD Deputy Chief Medical Officer Dr Jenny Harries, Health Secretary Matt Hancock and National Medical Director at NHS England Stephen Powis answer questions from the media via a video link during a media briefing in Downing Street today" content"https:www.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES sb _Coronavirus.jpg" Deputy Chief Medical Officer Dr Jenny Harries, Health Secretary Matt Hancock and National Medical Director at NHS England Stephen Powis answer questions from the media via a video link during a media briefing in Downing Street today :Workers should raise concerns with their bossesthey feel unsafeDeputy chief medical officer Dr Jenny Harries urged employers to distance employeesthey have to go into an office.#xCThe rule about the two metres is to ensure that we are consciously keeping apart from each other so we do not inadvertently pass on diseasewe have it...#xCThere are numerous occupations where you do not need to be at work. Some of them we have to and we recognise the support that our key workers are providing in that service but many don#xt need to be and I think we are encouraging our employers to think really carefully about how to innovate in the way their staff are working.#xCAndthey do need to be in the office, just to spread people around.#xDThe Health Secretary warned that enforcement action will be taken against businesses who remain open despite being ordered to close.Outlining the new rules, Mr Hancock: #xCIt is stay at home unless you#xve got a good reason and we will also enforce those rules.#xCIf you are in a workplace that we have said will close then we are going to enforce against those closures as well.#xDDeputy chief medical officer for England Dr Jenny Harries said iniduals should raise concerns with their bossesthey feel unsafe.#xCIf they don#xt feel that safety, then I think it is reasonable to highlight that very firmly with their employer,#xD she said.Dr Jenny Harries said workers who do not feel comfortable should raise concerns with their employers:Full report: Boyfriends and girlfriends who live apart should not visit each other’s housesThe Deputy Chief Medical Officer has confirmed boyfriends and girlfriends who live apart should not visit each other#xs houses.But she did offer a silver lining - saying lovers can move in with each other full-time and stay therethey want to take the plunge.Jenny Harries said: #xCIf your two halves of a couple are currently in separate households ideally they should stay in those households.#xCThe alternative might be that for quite a signicant period going forward, they should just test the strength of their relationship and decide whether one wishes to be permanently resident in another household.#xCWhat we do not want is people switching in and out of households.#xDRead the full report:Couples split apart should just test the strength of their relationshipAt the press briefing, Deputy Chief Medical Officer Jenny Harries has been asked about the issue of girlfriends and boyfriends who wish to be together but are currently in separate households. Dr Harries has said: #xCThe principle is that we want people to stay in their household units primarily.#xCThe reason for that isyou have an infection you are very close with your family members so your risk of exposure to the virus is pretty similar usually across a family. We almost expect another member of a family to get that unless they#xre applying very stringent precautions.#xCSoyou#xre two halves of a couple are currently in separate households ideally they should stay in those households.#xCThe alternative might be that for quite a signicant period going forward, they should just test the strength of their relationship and decide whether one wishes to be permanently resident in another household. In which case all the decisions about exercising, you should be on your own or in your household unit, would apply.#xCWhat we do not want is people switching in and out of households. It defeats the purpose of the reduction in social interactions and will allow transmission of disease.#xCSo perhaps test really carefully your strength of feeling. Stay with the household either together or apart but keep it that way while we go forward.#xDBrits should not visit their boyfriend#xs or girlfriend#xs housethey don#xt live together, Downing Street indicated earlier today.:Video: Matt Hancock announces NHS Volunteers:New make-sht hospital NHS Nightingale will open next week with  bedsMore on that new hospital now.Matt Hancock has confirmed that London#xs ExCeL centre will be turned into a makesht ,-bed #xCfield hospital#xD under NHS plans to cope when the peak of the coronavirus epidemic.The new hospital named NHS Nightingale will open next week to provide extra critical care capacity in the capital where the NHS is most stretched.Yesterday it was reported that the conference centre was turned into a massive critical care unit far bigger than any such facility already in existence in any NHS hospital.Experts from the Ministry of Defence were understood to be helping the project.Read the full report:KEY EVENT, volunteers needed to join NHS in virus fightHealth Secretary Matt Hancock has called on , to sign up to help the NHS through the coronavirus crisis.Mr Hancock also warned that the Prime Minister#xs lockdown regulations #xCare not requests, they are rules#xD.Giving a briefing at  Downing Street, he said a new hospital will be opened at the Excel Centre in East London.The temporary hospital will have two wards for , people, the Health Secretary stated.Mr Hancock said a call for people toto the NHS has been #xCincredibly successful#xD, with , people responding.Read the full story :Matt Hancock announces launch of NHS volunteers - seeking , people to volunteer to help services - and new make-sht hospital in LondonHe has begun by reiterating the drastic measures announced by Boris Johnson.And he is announcing the launch of #xNHS volunteers#x. A new scheme so people can volunteer to help NHS services and local services.He is seeking , volunteers to help the health service.He has also announced a new temporary hospital which will be built at the Excel Centre in London. It will be called NHS Nightingale, and will comprise two wards each of , people. #xWith the help of the military we will make sure we have capacity we need so everyone can get the support they need.#xAlso, , people have answered the call toto the NHS, he said. Meanwhile final year medics and student nurses will be moved to the health service front line. More follows.:Daily press briefing any minute nowHeads-up, very shortly we will hear from Matt Hancock, the Health Secretary. He will be holding a press briefing.This will be carried out remotely - as the minister aims to show he is leading by example.Stay tuned.:The largest day-on-day increase in the number of deaths since the outbreak beganToday#xs rise in coronavirus-related deaths across the UK from  to  is a jump of  and is the largest day-on-day increase in the number of deaths since the outbreak began.It is also a rise of %, which is not the biggest percentage day-on-day increase so far but is higher than the % increase reported yesterday.The UK#xs first coronavirus-related death was recorded on March . It took another  days for the number of deaths to pass  , then three more days to pass  . It has taken a further three days for the total to pass .- via PA:Some information about where the latest deaths occurredAccording to NHS England,  of the deaths were reported at London North West University Healthcare NHS Trust in Harrow.A further seven died at the Princess Alexandra Hospital in Harlow, Essex, while four died at each of Manchester University NHS Foundation Trust, University Hospitals of Leicester and Leeds Teaching Hospitals NHS Trust.This does not, of course, account for al lthe  new deaths reported in England alone. :Latest from IrelandTaoiseach Leo Varadkar has urged everyone to stay at home to slow the spread of Covid-.Speaking at a Government briefing in Dublin, he said: #xCWe believe we need to do more to flatten the curve. People should stay at homeat all possible - this is the best way to slow the virus.#xDAll cafes and restaurants should limit supply to takeaway only. All theatres, clubs, bingo halls and non-essential retail should close.All sporting events, even those behind closed doors, are cancelled.Mr Varadkar confirmed the Government is to increase the Covid- Pandemic Unemployment Support payment for people who have been laid off due to the virus from  euro to  euro.The payment will also apply to the self-employed who are affected by Covid-.An emergency wage subsidy scheme under which the Government will pay % of a worker#xs salary up to a cap of  euro per week net - equivalent to the after-tax income of a worker on around , euro.All gatherings outdoors are limited to a maximum of four people but not in the case of families. Mr Varadkar said more park rangers will be present to ensure social distancing measures are complied with.Gardai will #xCincrease interventions#xD to ensure compliance with the measures but such interventions will be used #xCsparingly#xD, he said.:Number of deaths in England onlyThe number of deaths in England alone rose by  in  hours .As of am on Monday, NHS England said a further  people had died in England, bringing the total number of deaths there to .Patients were aged between  and  years old and all were in vulnerable groups including those with underlying conditions.As of am on Tuesday, a total of , people have been tested, with , positive results, up from , at the same point on Monday.Two people died in the last day in Scotland, bringing the total to  - title: coronavirus may infected half uk
story: NewsCoronavirus may have infected half of UK population, researchers sayThe University of Oxfords Evolutionary Ecology of Infectious Disease group found that far more people in the UK could have contracted coronavirus than previously thoughtShareCommentsByMatthew Dresch:,  MAR NewsCoronavirus may have infected more than half of the UK population, according to new research " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailCoronavirus may have already infected more than half the UK population, researchers say. University of Oxford Professor Sunetra Gupta said it could mean less than one in a thousand people who contract the disease will need hospital treatment.  The theoretical epidemiology expert added that large-scale anti-body testing surveys now need to take place to confirm how many people have been infected.Research by Oxford’s Evolutionary Ecology of Infectious Disease group suggests coronavirus was spreading in the UK by mid-January.It was transmitted between people for more than a month before the first official cases were recorded. Do you have a coronavirus story  Email webnews@mirror Despite the findings, Professor Gupta refused to criticise the Governmentaposs approach, claiming social distancing will help to reduce stress on the NHS as less people will fall ill.The study drew on death and case reports from the UK and Italy, the Financial Times reports.It may spark fresh debate over the Governmentaposs aposherd immunityapos strategy, which envisioned a large proportion of the population getting the infection to end the outbreak.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailParents have taken on the role as unpaid teachers as millions start their home-schooling plans. It comes after measures taken by the government to stop the spread of coronavirus saw all schools close - except to the children of key workers and those who are more vulnerable. The move has forced thousands of parents to juggle working from home with teaching their children a whole range of subjects they would otherwise be working on with trained professionals. Some parents have taken their roles pretty seriously and drawn up timetables for their children to keep learning  at home. Others have even been sticking to routine and dressing children in schools unroms. Some have been giving their children the same break and lunch times offered in school - with packed lunches made up to eat at the dinner table.Kim Kenlay said on Twitter : Our own school timetable, created to keep the kids busy learning. Her plans for the week included cooking classes, outdoor play and PE. Another parent, Nasar Meer, a Professor at Edinburgh University, posted a robust timetable he had planned for the week. His lessons included Spanish, religious education and even yoga. He shared a picture of the timetable on Twitter, saying: Right then, P #homeschooling here we come. Naturally this will collapse into telly and crisps, but we tried. Wish us luck! Many parents have shared their hilarious experiences of home-schooling already - with some suggesting teachers are clearly vastly underpaid. Some have taken their home schooling into the garden. Thoma Anker said: My  yrs old was asked to dig a hole in the garden. My  yrs old was challenged to count the worms and measure the size of the hole. Big brother should then calculate total number of worms in our garden. They even enjoyed themselves.  Home-schooling for the parents of Britainaposs biggest family The Radfords however looked more like an ordinary classroom as they worked with some of their  children. Pregnant Sue Radford shared a picture of her kids learning to the familyaposs facebook page with the caption aposDay one of homeschooling there probably won’t be a day two. She added the hashtags #gotmyownclass #literally. Her comment is probably something felt by millions of parents across the UK as they struggle to balance working from home with homeschooling their children.  Sue, who is around  weeks pregnant and in self-isolation, was due to deliver her baby girl in two weeks but is now thinking about postponing her induction. She told Sun Online: “For the past kind of, I would say, since the middle of last week, I was thinking do I still go for my induction in the middle of next week’s time. The government was previously criticised for failing to close schools soon enought - however they said all scientic advice on what measures to take and when were being followed.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email Pets should be kept insidetheir owners are self isolating with coronavirus symptoms, a charity has warned. Experts say there is still no evidence that pets such as dogs and cats are a source of infection to other animals or humans, although there are other coronaviruses that have been in the UK for years, such as respiratory   infections in dogs.And with Brits limited to how often they can leave the house daily following Prime Minister Boris Johnsonaposs address to the nation on Monday night, it has left pet owners confused as to what impact it will have on their animals. Blue Cross has answered the many questions on pet owners minds. The charity say those social distancing can still take their dog for a walk and exercise once a day but they MUST keep their distance from other people by at least two metres. However,self isolating because they, or a member of their household, has had signs of the disease they should not go out at all. Someone from outside of the household may have to take their dog out for them. Owners can ask friends, neighbours or family membersthey can help and there are also increasingly numbers of community groups offering to walk dogs and pick up essential pet supplies. Affected owners can check local media and social media to find someone in their area.  Volunteer dog walkers should use their own dog lead or disinfect the owner’s lead. It is important pet owners wash their hands after handling their pets, andunwell and self isolating it is also a good idea to avoid other people stroking and handling their pets. If pets aren’t getting their usual amount of exercise it is important owners make up for this to keep pets healthy and mentally stimulated. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA sobering photograph shows five solitary chairs set aside for mourners at a UK crematorium as stricter rules come into force today. The poignant images captures the heartbreaking reality grieving families are having to face amid the Covid- outbreak. The five chairs were placed two metres apart ahead of a service at an unidentied crematorium on Monday.The heartbreaking scene captured how the stricter coronavirus distancing rules have been introduced for funerals as Britain goes into lockdown.It comes as venues across the nation introduce tougher rules for funerals, with some limiting the number of mourners to five or just immediate family. Boris Johnson announced funerals will still be allowed to go ahead, despite banning other social events such as weddings and christenings.Those grieving deaths have already been advised to avoid hugging, kissing or shaking hands when consoling loved ones as well as not handling orders of service. Now local authorities are stepping up measures to reduce capacity at crematoriums in light of the Prime Ministeraposs announcement on Monday night. One clergyman, who wished to remain anonymous, said: It breaks your heart to see scenes like this when conducting a service. Funerals should be a celebration of someoneaposs le, with friends and family surrounding each other for support and being able to hug each other. To see them reduced to such tiny numbers of people is a sad reminder of the crisis we are facing as a nation at the moment.  One funeral director in Worcester has revealed some funerals are going ahead without anybody in attendance to say their final farewells due to the coronavirus fears. Mark Campion, director of Jackson Family Funeral Directors, said many cremations were now being carried out without a funeral service beforehand to be safer. He also said a vicar held out a broomstick at a recent service to keep people apart and other upcoming funerals due to have hundreds in the congregation will now only be attended by three close family members. He added: Things have dramatically changed for us. I have not seen anything like this in  years. I just feel so sorry for the families because they canapost say goodbye to their loved ones like they usually would. Itaposs extremely sad for the families.Guidelines, published by the Funeral Celebrancy Council and issued by Humanists UK, advise families only have essential attendees who must obey social distancing rules. Isabel Russo, head of ceremonies at Humanists UK, said: Our main priority is ensuring that we support bereaved families to say farewell to their loved one in a personal and meaningful way, while still following the guidelines to keep people safe. We are also urging the Government to issue specic advice for the funeral industry to bring clarity across the sector. The Funeral Celebrant Councilaposs Independent celebrant rep, Emma Curtis said: Over the last week funeral celebrants around the country have felt a great deal of anxiety. The Funeral Celebrancy Council has responded swtly to issue clear guidelines to funeral celebrants as a coherent approach to help protect, not only the health and welfare of the bereaved people we serve, but also our fellow professionals, and wider society.  York Crematorium now only allows five mourners at a time and offers video streams of funeral services in a bid to stop the spread of the virus. Elsewhere, The London Cremation Company, has followed suit and is only permitting  mourners at a time. Dudley Council has written to funeral directors saying only next of kin, siblings and partners, parents, children and partners, and a carerapplicable, will be allowed to attend cremations .

Richard Walker, the managing director of Iceland Foods, posted a photo online today showing a pair of branded vehicles completely destroyed by the blaze. The damage by yobs took place during wider destruction in the Henbury and Southmead areas of Bristol late last night. Police have since stepped up local patrols after branding the crimes, thought to be the actions of youths, as reckless and thoughtless. In a statement, Iceland said the disturbances began at around .pm. Do you have a coronovirus story  Email  webnews@mirror Police riot vans were called out and youths threw missiles at the police as they tried to disperse them, the retailer said. Later in the evening the two home delivery vans parked outside our Southmead store were set alight and the fire brigade attended to put out the fire. The vans will both have to be written off. We believe this to be an act of mindless vandalism rather than a targeted attack on Iceland. It added: While we can and will bring in replacement vans to maintain our home delivery service in Southmead, our entire van fleet is running at absolutely full capacity at the moment, and it is shocking and distressing that anyone would act so callously to put vehicles out of service at precisely the time when they are most needed to deliver food to the most vulnerable people in our society. The shocking acts came just hours after Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced that people should only venture outside for essential reasons to beat coronavirus. Posting on Twitter, Mr Walker said:  of our vans in Southmead were burnt out last night during disturbances in the town.At a time when home delivery is literally a leline for some vulnerable people, this is sickening. As well as the torched vans, police also received reports of bricks being thrown through windows and cars being smashed up between pm and :am. Neighbourhood Chief Inspector Mark Runacres, of Avon and Somerset Constabulary, issued a stern warning to others thinking of carrying out the same acts again. He said: Just hours after the Prime Minister announced that everyone in the country should stay home to save lives it is beyond belief that anyone would be so reckless and thoughtless.

title: dad left unable smell newborn
story: NewsDad left unable to smell newborn baby after thug batters him in drunken attackPaul Williams was beaten so badly he has been left with a permanent headache and no sense of taste or smell. His skull, cheek, nose and eye socket were all brokenShareCommentsByCiaran JonesJamie Hawkins:,  MAR NewsConnor Jonesbeat Paul Williams to the ground and left him with a permanent headache and no sense of taste or smell. His skull, cheek, nose and eye socket were all broken " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe victim of a drunken attack suffered le-changing injuries and has been left unable to work or even smell his baby boy. Dad-of-six Paul Williams was beaten to the ground by Connor Jones, who walked away but ed to the stricken man minutes later and, while others were trying to help the casualty, cruelly kicked him in the head.Ten months after the attack, Paul is still suffering with memory and language problems and has lost his senses of taste and smell, reports Wales Online. The man who changed his le has been jailed for six years. Swansea Crown Court heard it was not known what caused the attack though the two men were known to each other having both been carrying out community service work the week before. Robin Rouch, prosecuting, said in the early hours of April  last year Mr Williams was out socialising in Llanelli town centre. Just before .am he became involved in an “altercation” with other men near Bar Luna. Jones then approached the group and attacked the victim, punching him a number of times and knocking him to the floor. The court heard Mr Williams remained on the ground for a minute before getting to his feet at which point Jones punched him down again. Mr Williams managed to get to a nearby wall and sat down but Jones followed him. The prosecutor said a “tussle” then ensued and Jones was seen to carry out “two stamping motions” – though the court heard the defendant denies he stamped on his victim. Jones left the scene but ed a couple of minutes later. By now his victim was lying helpless on the floor being tended by passers-by but the defendant walked up to him and kicked him a number of times to the head. The court heard Mr Williams has no memory of the prolonged attack. The last thing he can remember is leaving the town’s Met bar at around .am and heading towards the Asda supermarket. His next recollection is waking up in bushes near a chapel in the town centre.He managed to stumble home and at around am his we was woken by a “loud bang” at the door. She went downstairs and found her husband being sick and with blood over his face. An ambulance was called and he was rushed to hospital. A subsequent CT scan showed fractures to the cheek, nose, and eye socket bones, and to the skull, as well as multiple contusions to the brain. He had to spend two days in the emergency department. Jones, of Clos Dewi Medi, Morfa, Llanelli, admitted inflicting grievous bodily harm with intent. The court heard he has a number of previous convictions, though none for offences of violence, and was on a community order at the time of the attack for possession of cannabis and stealing lead from a roof. Dean Pulling, for Jones, said the defendant was remorseful for what he had done and accepted a prison sentence was inevitable.  The barrister said: “This incident is an advert for the pernicious effects of too much alcohol and drugs on young men out late at night.” He added that his client had spent three weeks on remand prior to sentencing which had been his first taste of custody – “an experience he has not found pleasant”. Judge Keith Thomas told Jones he had involved himself in a dispute between other people before punching his victim then “coming for him again” with his feet. Giving the defendant a discount for his guilty plea he sentenced him to six years in prison. Jones will serve half that period in custody before being released on licence to serve the remainder in the community. He was also made the subject of a restraining order banning him from contacting Mr Williams for the next seven years.

story: NewsHow to survive coronavirus lockdown - one mans tips after  days in flatConor Brady, from Belfast, has spent  days in his flat in Paris due to the coronavirus lockdown, and admitted it has been really hard, but has shared advice on how to copeShareCommentsByAine FoxJamie Hawkins:,  MAR NewsA man reads a book on the balcony of his appartement in central Paris on the eight day of a strict lockdown in France " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email A man who has spent more than a week on coronavirus lockdown has advised people to take things one day at a time and allow themselves an occasional wobble.Conor Brady, from Belfast, described the first  days of being cooped up in his small apartment in Paris as really hard but said having some kind of structure to the day and setting small tasks is key to coping with such a drastic lestyle change. The -year-old has left the -square metre flat only to go for a jog alone or buy groceries - and carries a certicate with him to state his reason for being outside should he be stopped by police. Do you have a coronavirus story to share  Email  webnews@mirror  Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced in a televised address to the nation on Monday night sweeping measures for the UK, including people remaining indoors except for exercise once a day and shopping trips for necessities only.Mr Brady, a policy analyst on secondment in the French capital until June, told the PA news agency: The key thing is donapost look at the endgame, donapost look at the lockdown in its totality. I made that mistake last Monday and had a bit of a wobble, knowing that Iaposm basically not going to see or interact with another human for another couple of months.  The most important thing Iaposve found just for psychological well-being and mental health is - and I know it sounds like a trite cliche but - one day at a time. He spends  minutes before bed each night planning the next day which includes dedicating an hour to an online exercise class, and has made a list of films he has always wanted to watch.  Everybody is going to suffer from a wobble, he said. Everybody will have moments where they just look at it from a macro rather than a micro perspective and thataposs so daunting, so intimidating. But allow yourself that wobble and then get back on the horse again.  Mr Brady said he had seriously considered ing home to Northern Ireland when French President Emmanuel Macron gave notice of the lockdown last week, but felt it would have been irresponsible to do so. He said: I had a window of opportunity to travel and I just thought I couldnapost in good conscience be that irresponsible because I might be carrying the virus. I might be asymptomatic. How irresponsible would it be of me to come from an area of high incidence and take it back home  I just thought this is a level of social responsibility I need to take, not for me but for other people. Despite his positive mindset he admitted it is an extra challenge to be away from family and unable to help his self-isolating parents who fall into the category of people urged to stay at home for at least the next  weeks.  He said: Donapost get me wrong, itaposs really hard. The frustration is that Iaposm not there to support my family as much as I could bebut weaposre all pulling together as much as we can. The family WhatsApp has never been busier. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email A mother has revealed how her perfectly healthy five-year-old son was struck down with coronavirus.Lauren Fulbrook, , from Bromyard, Worcestershire, explained how Alfie’s symptoms included a temperature of more than C, hallucinations and vomiting.The carer took to Facebook to speak out as she wanted to warn parents that even children without underlying health conditions can contract Covid-.Lauren said she feared for Alfie’s le as he was lying helplessly on a hospital bed and asked her: Mummy, am I going to die  The mother-of-two wrote on Facebook in a post that’s been shared more than , times: Coronavirus is NOT a joke.Please stop brushing it under the carpet and putting not only your own lives at risk but everyone aposs just because you want to go to the pub, or to a restaurant or think you need  packs of  toilet rolls, as a Covid- positive household, Iaposve seen the effects it has. His temperature wouldnapost go below the s and at its highest was . which caused vomiting. I watched him hallucinating and crying from his headache, being taken to hospital by ambulance to be put in isolation pods and be swabbed for the virus and confirmed positive. Lauren described it as the worst experience of her le when Alfie first started to show symptoms on Monday March .  Her post continued: His blood sugar levels were only ., his respiratory rate was - and his heart rate was , the sweat was pouring out of him but he was shivering, he was panting for breath and he had photophobia. Lauren ended her post with a defiant message directed to those who are ignoring government advice to stay at home during the global crisis.  She pleaded: So please, just stay in for a little while, so whatyou canapost do all your normal things, the sooner everybody does social distancing, the sooner it will be over. I am not posting this for attention or sympathy, as I could have done that the day he got sick, I just want people to stay safe. Please think of your health and others. The health effects of the Covid- outbreak have generally been milder on children but many unknowns remain.  The mother detailed how Alfie deteriorated after he attended a swimming lesson last week. She said: He started off sounding husky last Monday and I put it down to swallowing too much chlorine from his swimming lesson that day, then he got a bark-like cough and it worsened throughout Tuesday, then his temperature suddenly kicked in Tuesday night and it shot straight to . so I had to keep him off school. He wasn’t eating, hardly drinking and said he couldn’t move.’ So I rang  and they sent an ambulance out in the morning, but they said that the hospital was so busy they couldn’t take him in. They got his temperature down and saidit went back up or he got worse to ring . Describing the scary moment her little boy was rushed off in an ambulance on Thursday afternoon, Lauren continued: Later that evening he was vomiting, hallucinating, crying, holding his head saying it felt like it was going to explode and his eyes were hurting, so the ambulance came out and said we had to go back in. As Lauren also suffered from a cough, she was allowed to stay by Alfie’s side after the paramedics and a nurse gave them a bed in the isolation unit following his positive coronavirus results. After being kept overnight from Thursday until Friday evening, Lauren said the hospital allowed them tohome with strict isolation restrictions. She said: ‘‘The hospital advised that as long as I could give Alfie medicine - I would be able to self-isolate us all at home. He’s still recovering now after a week and a day. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA loss of appetite and of your sense of smell are two of the milder symptoms of coronavirus people should look out for. It is now almost two months since the first coronavirus case was confirmed in the UK. In the weeks since, most people have become aware that a newly formed dry, persistent cough and a fever are two of the tell-tale signs of Covid-. There are also milder, less obvious symptoms to look out for. Below are some of the signals that may suggest you have been infected. Have you fallen ill with Covid-  Email webnews@trinitymirror Loss of sense of smell and taste Over the weekend the British Association of Otorhinolaryngology warned that losing your sense of smell and taste may mean you have Covid-. The ear, nose and throat specialist recommended anyone with such symptoms self-isolate immediatley. It has been suggested that the phenomena may be caused by the coronavirus killing cells in the nose and throat. Evidence from other countries that the entry point for the coronavirus is often in the eyes, nose and throat areas, the Association said in a statement. We have also identied a new symptomthat may mean that people without other symptoms but with just the loss of this sense may have to self-isolate - again to reduce the spread of the virus. Ryan Van Waterschoot ended up in hospital relying on an oxygen mask after he fell ill with Covid-. A day after losing his sense of taste and smell he was unable to move. Physical fatigue     Another common symptom of Covid-, as well as cold, flu and many viruses in general, is feeling tired or fatigued. Being told to rest is common when you’re ill, but feeling tired and not being able to sleep due to coughs and dficulty breathing, can make things all the more dficult. Jaimuay Sae-ung, , was the first Thai national to contract coronavirus in December last year. Despite having underlying health conditions, including a heart problem, Jaimuay survived the illness after doctors isolated her at a hospital in Thailand for treatment. I only knewafter I came to the hospital, the mother of seven told Sky News. I felt a bit sad, a bit shocked, tired and fatigued and I couldnapost eat. Those experiencing coronavirus symptoms, such as a cough or fever, should self-isolate for  days.You should stay at homeyou or or anyone in your household has a high temperature or a new and continuous cough - evenitaposs mild. Everyone in your household must stay at home for  days and keep away from others DO NOT go to your GP or hospital.Go to NHS.UK to check your symptoms and follow the specialist medical advice.Only call you canapost get online, you feel like you canapost cope at home, or your symptoms do not get better after the seven days. If you are pregnant you should call you have any concerns about yourself or unborn baby during self-isolation. Pregnant women are advised to contact their midwe, out-of-hours helplines or a maternity team who will provide information on whether you need to go to hospital.  Mental fatigue Although this has not been officially chalked up as a symptom, Covid- sufferers have reported experiencing mental fatigue. Thea Jourdan told The Daily Mail that she first thought she may have been infected when she got a tickle in her throat and a headache. The mum-of-three then began to experience brain fog. Initially I felt exhausted, asI was dragging myself through treacle and had no choice but to go to my bed. I had no meaningful cough and I wasn’t running a fever, the Hampshire woman told the publication. But I had a peculiar sensation of something settling deep within my lungs, almost like breathing in talcum powder. Lack of appetite    To ying degrees those who have caught the coronavirus have complained of losing their appetite. While some may be just a little less intrigued by their food than usual, others, such as racing blogger Stephen Power, have no desire at all to eat. He believes he contracted the disease while at Cheltenham Festival. The North West London man said: Iaposve been in bed with a nasty fever, headache, mild cough  back pain for nearly four days now, Iaposm completely exhausted and have no urge to move or eat. Tummy ache    As with a loss of appetite, enduring a tummy ache may easily be passed off as a sign of something more innocuous. I don’t believe you made any wrong conscious choices, and neither did I. The second phone call was to Tim - they were friends before they got into a relationship, and dated for a couple of months about three years ago.  Rebecca desperately tried to break up with him, claiming it was impossible to do so - and even said that she was confused about her sexuality - which Tim was so understanding as to offer to work things out together. But it turns out Tim still thought sheaposd ended things really out of the blue especially since sheaposd even brought him gts the day before. Eve though she blocked him, it didnapost stop Tim from apologising after she had ended things. He turned up at her house with a photo album which he had decorated himself with writing and flowers. He said: I do wanna say, and I feel this is a good time to say it, that I’m sorry for after it happened and I came to your house, still feel like a dick about it years later. And his one piece of advice: It’s the cutting people off really - like for the longest time I assumed you just got bored of me. The third and final call was to Ed - her first kiss.  And, since the pair are still friends he wasnapost afraid to be a little more heartless with his advice. He revealed the pair had only been together for three days and said Rebecca should have had the the b******s to dump me yourself after Rebecca had her scary friend do the deed for her. He soon got back to the task at hand, suggesting these improvements: One, confidence. Two, you could have been a bit more passionate, a bit more affectionate.
